p: Cardiac injury was also common in the infection caused by other subtypes of influenza virus ( 6â€“ 10, 14, 15, 20, 28). A retrospective studies found that about 54% individuals infected during the severe H1N1 pandemic in 2009 had cardiac injury ( 9). A study of 600 U.S. patients who underwent cardiac biomarker testing within 30 days after a laboratory-confirmed influenza infection specimen collection showed that 143 (24%) had elevated TNI and/or CK-MB ( 29). Severe infections, ARDS, and related mechanical ventilation settings were associated with cardiac injury ( 12, 30). These common conditions in patients with H7N9 viral infection may partly explain the high proportion of cardiac injury ( 3).
